course.course_description: Examines the multiple spaces of globalization from an anthropological and architectural/urbanistic perspective, through a combination of theoretical readings and case studies.

Mediterranean World After Alexander the Great

course.course_description: Explores the social functioning of images in the representation of self and others in the imagining of communities and nations in a colonial and postcolonial context.  Combines theoretical readings on iconography with practical exercises in the sociological observation of iconographic, performative, and oral source materials, examples from Latin America, Asia and Africa.

The Orient and the Western Musical Imagination.

Giacomo Leopardi In His European Context: a Comparative Perspective.
An Introduction To the Ethnography of South Asia
Nationalism and Modernity In Indian Literature
The Music and Writings of Wagner.
Gender and Sexuality In Ancient Greece
The Politics of Culture and Memory
course.course_description: A cross-disciplinary and transnational inquiry into issues of memory in the contemporary world.  Topics include the relation between history and public memory, modes and media of memory (photography, film, testimony, monuments, and museums) and changing notions of time, space, and the uses of the past.

course.course_name: Exploring East European Identities Through Literature and Film
Theory and Practice In the Study of Culture
Faust: German Myth In European Context
Poets and Critics: Salinas and Rodriguez
Topics In World Cinema: Africa and Arabia
Beyond Translation: the Challenge of Bilingual Writing In Africa
course.course_description: Case study in creative writing across linguistic and cultural boundaries in a colonial and post-colonial situation.  Readings from a wide variety of African writers.  Focus on the writings and multi-media practice of Kofi Anyidoho.

course.course_name: The Spanish American Novel of the Dictator [In Spanish]

course.course_description: Caribbean societies and the global system.

course.course_name: Spectacle Culture(S): the Aesthetics of Exorbitance From the Baroque To the Postmodern
course.course_description: An interdisciplinary examination of the mechanisms and ideological effects of spectacle culture, with particular attention to the aesthetics of exorbitance that governs its textual productions and its attempt to spectacularize all dimensions of the life-world from the environment to self-fashioning.
